newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Two Geneva private banks to merge.
newsitem.headline: Two Geneva private banks to merge.

text.p: Geneva private banks Banque D'Investissements Prives (BIP) and Compagnie Bancaire Geneve (CBG) will merge to join forces against growing competition, BIP director general Alain Peytral said on Thursday.

Peytral told Reuters that CBG would take over BIP by the end of March to form a new bank with a capital of 110 million Swiss Francs ($75 million) and combined assets under management of more than 6 billion Swiss Francs ($4.1 billion).
The merger would be completed by end-1997 and Peytral would stay as director general. No lay-offs were foreseen.
No sum was disclosed for the deal, but banking sources put it at well over 50 million Swiss Francs ($34 million)
Competition is heating up in the Swiss private banking arena following the arrival of Wall Street powerhouses like Merrill Lynch, forcing old, established banks to be more aggressive.
Some Swiss bankers are worried about fee erosion and many expect mergers and acquisitions to pick up pace this year.
Peytral said: "Competition is tough. We need a good size, a better team and more efficiency to deal with it. We have to work harder to make profits grow."
CBG is owned 60 percent by two private Swiss shareholders and the remainder by Banque Cantonale de Geneve.
The majority shareholders of BIP, founded in 1951, are two Luxembourg-based companies controlled by Belgian and French groups -- Socfinasia and Socfinal.

Earlier this month, U.S. brokerage house Lehman Brothers sold its fully-owned Swiss private bank in Geneva to Vancouver-based Canadian asset management and financial services group MFC Financial Corp for an undisclosed sum.
